msIdentifier.repository: Perne Library: on long-term deposit at Cambridge University Library

summary.seg: Peterhouse MS 247 is a medical compendium containing works by Hippocrates, Galen and others, which texts formed the basic curriculum - the ars medicine - of a university-trained doctor. It is one of only three manuscripts to have survived from the Augustinian priory of Lanercost in Cumbria. The priory's position close to the Scottish border left it subject to frequent cross-border raids, vividly recounted in the Lanercost Chronicle (London, British Library, Cotton MS Claudius D.VII). The third manuscript, containing the house's cartulary, is preceded by a register of writs (Carlisle, Cumbria County Record Office MS DZ/1). The Chronicle and cartulary/register were written in-house in the mid-fourteenth century. Peterhouse MS 247, meanwhile, was written elsewhere, in England or France, and professionally produced in small, neat rotunda bookhands dating from the late twelfth to the early fourteenth century. Guide letters remain in the margins of the first section of the manuscript, ff. 1-44, indicating what initials should be provided; these have been supplied in red or blue. Assembled from different sources, ff. 1-44 came from a larger volume perhaps produced in Paris, since a note on f. 34v refers to pecia production: 'xma pecia debet incipi hac in linea'. The pecia system appears not to have been adopted in England.

Since this compendium was compiled from different booklets, some of the texts have been repeated. Thus, both Hippocrates' Aphorismi and Prognostica are each present, written in three different copies, each produced on different occasions. Complete copies of the Prognostica are found three times (ff. 5r-11r, 113r-120v, and 156r-160r). One copy of the Aphorismi begins imperfectly in Book IV (ff. 1r-5r), and elsewhere only a single leaf survives of another copy (f. 169rv). A fuller text is found elsewhere in a separate booklet (ff. 95r-111v).

The manuscript has been heavily used, as extensive marginalia throughout in tiny glossing hands bears witness. Some annotations refer to texts which are not in Peterhouse MS 247. Thus, the annotator of Johannitius' Isagoge (ff. 162r-168v), an introduction to Galen's Tegni and central to the Articella, twice refers to works by 'Filosofus' (i.e. Aristotle). On f. 162v, the reference is to his De generatione ('Filosofus in secundo de generacione dicit...'), while that on f. 168v is to De animalibus ('Filosofus dicit quod omne animal habet vnam mandibulam...'). Medical texts were first taught in Paris within the framework of Aristotle’s works on natural philosophy.

The manuscript belonged to Lanercost by 1354 at the latest, when John of Bewcastle, prior 1338-54, had the use of it: 'Liber Fratris Nicholai de Morland ex dono Willelmi de Langedale cuius vsum proprium idem Nicholaus concessit cessit (sic) domini Johanni de Buchcaster' (f. 175r, the last leaf). Bewcastle, Morland and Langdale are all Cumbrian place names. An ex-libris is also found on f. 79r, at the end of the second booklet: 'Liber sancte marie magdalene de lanrecost. Si quis inde eum asportauerit anthema sit'. A note in yet another booklet - 'contra H de Burgo', at the foot of f. 115v - probably refers to Prior Henry, d. 1315. His verses commenting on local events and national affairs are found in the Lanercost Chronicle: a rubric by one short poem records 'Hugo de Burgo scripsit' (Chronicle, fol. 195v). How the manuscript reached Peterhouse is unknown.

Pam Robinson
Institute of English Studies, University of London

Bibliography:
Chronicon de Lanercost MCCI-MCCCCXLIV, ed. by Joseph Stevenson, Bannatyne Club (Edinburgh, 1839), pp. 105-47
Cornelius O'Boyle, The Art of Medicine: Medical Teaching at the University of Paris, 1250-1400, Education and Society in the Middle Ages and Renaissance, 9 (Leiden: Brill, 1998)
A.G. Rigg, A History of Anglo-Latin Literature 1066-1422 (Cambridge University Press, 1992), pp. 227-8
Henry Summerson, 'The History of Lanercost Priory', in Lanercost Priory, Cumbria: A Survey and Documentary History, ed. by Henry Summerson and Stuart Harrison, Transactions of the Cumberland and Westmorland Antiquarian and Archaeological Society, Research Series 10 (2000), pp. 1-80

supportDesc.support: Composite manuscript comprised of five major Parts and several fragments, all of parchment.

foliation.note: Foliated in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of each recto. The folio designation f. 41A was duplicated in error, and a Peterhouse librarian has redesignated the second f. 41 as 41A.

N.B.: When this manuscript was examined by M. R. James for his Catalogue of the Peterhouse manuscripts, he described the folio designations in this manuscript per-part, i.e., Part I pp. 1-45, Part II pp. 1-34 etc., rather than in a single foliation sequence from the beginning to the end of the manuscript.

Peterhouse MS 247 was rebound in 2023 and underwent extensive conservation and repair at that time. During the 2023 rebinding, the former pastedowns were lifted and have been assigned designations during the production of this catalogue record, f. [ia] for the former left pastedown, and f. [179] for the former right pastedown. During the 2023 rebinding, two new parchment endleaves were added at each end of the volume, these leaves have been assigned designations ff. [a]-[b] and [c]-[d] respectively. All of the leaves assigned designations during the production of this catalogue record have their designations enclosed in [square brackets] throughout the record.

collation.p: A composite manuscript comprised of five major parts and several fragments. The medieval endleaves at both ends of the volume (ff. [ia]-i-ii and ff. 176-[179] derive from a single original manuscript. The main quires are occasionally irregular with leaves both lost and added. In Part 4, each of the main texts was copied on a physically distinct booklet or group of booklets, as follows: ff. 79-94 (Quires 10-11), 95-112 (Quires 12-13), 113-121 (Quire 14) and 122-155 (Quires 15-17). The text on Quires 15-17 ends imperfectly, indicating the loss of one or more quires after Quire 17.

list.item: Medieval endleaves - three leaves (ff. [ia]-i-ii. Three leaves from the same manuscript as ff. 176-[179] |
Quire 202+1+1 (ff. 170-173; bifolium with two inserted singletons after the first leaf) |
Folios 176-[179] - four leaves from the same manuscript as the [ia]-i-ii

note.p: 20th-century quire designations in pencil in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire. Quires are lettered alphabetically, and the sequence restarts for each part, e.g., A-E | A-F etc. '+' marks the location of the central bifolium of each quire.

binding.p: Rebound in September 2023 by James Cassels. Tawed goat skin over quarter-sawn oak boards. Two silver pin-and-ring fore edge fastenings with tawed goatskin and vellum straps. Four raised bands on spine; double linen cords fitted to the medieval sewing stations. Head and tail bands of linen and finished with decorative sewing of alternate blue and cream segments.
Handmade paper pastedowns pasted over the turn ins. Two parchment endleaves (unphotographed) added at each end of the volume, ff. [a]-[b] and [c]-[d] respectively, all blank.
Medieval parchment pastedowns lifted; the newly free leaves assigned the designations ff. [ia] and [179] respectively.

Peterhouse MS 247 is now stored in an archival box made from acid free mill board, covered with archival buckram, and lined with museum board. The box also contains an archival folder which contains the remains of the 18th century binding and a printed description by James Cassels of the conservation and rebinding work undertaken in 2023.
Binding dimensions (L x W x D):

18th-century binding preserved in an archival folder stored in the manuscript box after the September 2023 rebinding. Cover is a washed and reused 18th century legal document (perhaps an indenture) over thin rope-fibre boards. Boards attached by laced cords glued into three saw-cuts across the spine. Traces of 4 double-twisted tawed leather supports for an earlier casing visible and cut at the joints.

Description of the contents of the volume written in ink on the spine in an 18th century hand. Small printed paper label fixed to the spine with an adhesive bearing the shelfmark designation '247'. 'Peterhouse Library 247' written in pencil on the left cover.

provenance.p:
The manuscript is a composite and is comprised of nine distinct Parts. Two of the Parts (Parts 4 and 9) have inscriptions demonstrating that they were the property of members of the community of Lanercost PrioryLanercost Priory (Gilsland, England) in Cumbria by the middle of the 14th century, and it possible that all Parts of Peterhouse MS 247 were copied or at least compiled at Lanercost Priory. Part 4 (ff. 79-155, see f. 79r) has an inscription on its first leaf describing it as the property of the community of Lanercost Priory ('Liber Sancte Marie magdalene de Lanrecost
Si quis inde eum asportauerit anathema sit'), and Part 9 (f. 175, see f. 175r) has an inscription describing the gift of the book (in whatever form it was in then) as the possession of a particular monk, Nicholas of Morland, during John of Bewcastle's tenure as Prior (1338-1354). Please see the provenance information for Parts 4 and 9 and Pam Robinson's introduction to this catalogue record for further information. Several Parts of the manuscript share similar scribal and decorative features so it is possible that the entire volume existed in its current form at Lanercost in the 14th century. This manuscript (or, at least, some of its Parts) is one of only three surviving manuscripts known to have been owned and used at Lanercost Priory, the others being London, British Library, MS Cotton Claudius D vii ('The Lanercost Chronicle') and Carlisle, Cumbria County Record Office MS DZ/1.

acquisition.p: No acquisition information recorded. The manuscript was at Peterhouse in the 18th century, as it has a distinctive 18th century binding in common with several other Peterhouse manuscripts that were rebound by the College in that century.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws substantially on R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Woodbridge, 2016). Readers of this record are strongly encouraged to consult Thomson's Catalogue for further information. This catalogue entry also draws on M. R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Peterhouse (Cambridge, 1899). This catalogue record also draws on unpublished notes made by Dr Debby Banham in 1999 and 2000 as part of a survey of medical manuscripts in Cambridge.

availability.p: The majority of the western medieval manuscripts owned by Peterhouse, including MS 247, are on long-term deposit at Cambridge University Library. Entry to read in Cambridge University Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Woodbridge, 2016)
M. R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Peterhouse (Cambridge, 1899)

msItem.title: Partial list of the contents of the volume

note.p: Written in an English hand of 17th or 18th century appearance below the tables on f. ii recto

Full transcription:
Tractatus Hippocratis ...Galeni Aphorismi & Prognostica
Theophilius de Urinis
Philaretus de pulsis
Antidotarium cum glossula
Conferentia & nocentia
Joannicius
Galeni Tegni

collation.p:
Folios [ia]-i-ii and 176-[179] are a series of astronomical tables that derive from the same original manuscript, but are now split into two groups and part of Peterhouse MS 247 as the front and rear endleaves. Folios [ia] and [179] were pastedowns in the volume until they were lifted during conservation and repair work undertaken in 2023. Folios [ia]-i-ii are arranged as two nested bifolia, where ff. [ia]-i are cojoint and inserted upside down; these leaves seem to have been nested inside f. ii, and another leaf that has now been cut away. The present collation of folios 176-[179] is undetermined.
Medieval endleaves - three leaves (ff. [ia]-i-ii) |
- Intervening leaves -
Medieval endleaves - four leaves (ff. 176-[179])

supportDesc.condition: The leaves have been stabilised through conservation and repair but are generally in poor condition with numerous tears and cuts and loss of text due to rubbing and staining. Folio [ia] recto was a pastedown until conservation and repair work was undertaken on the volume in 2023, and is coated in an adhesive residue.

p.seg: The format varies, but all leaves in this Part are ruled for full-page tables in leadpoint. The tables typically have at least 30 rows and 25 columns; further calendrical and specific numerical information is recorded in the margins above and below most of the tables.

handNote.p: Written in a gothic rotunda by an English scribe.

note.p: Brief list of some of the contents of the volume on f. i recto in ink in an English hand of perhaps the 17th century.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 2 - Hippocrates, Theophilus, Philaretus, and Galen (Thomson Part I)

msItem.title: Aphorismata (Aphorisms) (tr. Constantinus Africanus) [Latin]
msItem.author: Hippocrates
msItem.incipit: 1r in natus malum . si inebriatus aliquis repente sine uoce fiat spasmo innato moritur
msItem.explicit: 5r Corporibus habentibus humidas carnes fames adhibere conuenit . fames enim siccat corpora

msItem.title: Prognostica (Prognostics) (tr. Constantinus Africanus or Gerard of Cremona) [Latin]
msItem.author: Hippocrates
msItem.incipit: 5r Omnis qui medicine artis studio seu gloriam . seu delectabilem amicorum consequi desiderat
msItem.explicit: 11r Quia determinantur quecumque nostro numero dierum morborum quoque sunt exposite ordine preceptorum

msItem.title: Liber urinarum (On Urines) [Latin]
msItem.author: Theophilus
msItem.incipit: 11r De urinarum differentia negocium multi ueterum medicorum agressi sunt
msItem.explicit: 19v conuenienter exposuimus

msItem.title: Liber pulsuum (On Pulses) [Latin]
msItem.author: Philaretus
msItem.rubric: 20r Incipit liber philareti de negocio pulsuum
msItem.incipit: 20r Intenconem habemus in presenti conscripcione de pulsuum negocio
msItem.explicit: 22r et delecta et mortem signum et hec nobis sufficiant ad presencia

msItem.title: Dieta Hippocratis per singulos menses anni obseruanda
msItem.incipit: 22v Mense ianuarii zinziber et reuponticum bibe sanguinem non minue calidem usita
msItem.explicit: 22v quia tunc omnes esce confecte sunt

msItem.title: Tegni (tr. Constantinus Africanus)
msItem.author: Galen
msItem.incipit: 23r Tres sunt omnes doctrine que ordine habentur
msItem.explicit: 44v et qualia determinabo orationem in eis
msItem.note: With prologue. Main text begins on f. 23r Medicina est scientia sanorum ....

msItem.title: Elegiae
msItem.author: Maximianus
msItem.incipit: 44r Emula quid cessas
msItem.explicit: 44r nam mea mens
msItem.note: Fragmentary text, perhaps a pen trial.

supportDesc.condition: Leaves trimmed with losses to marginal annotations. Margins of some leaves torn with losses to some marginal annotations and main text. Lower 40mm of f. 44 cut away entirely with loss of marginal annotations.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint in single-column format, frame and lines. Written below top line, typically 31 lines to the page. Most leaves have glosses and marginalia in the upper, lower and outer margins.

handNote.p: Written in a gothic rotunda by a ?French scribe.

decoNote.p: Puzzle initials (red and blue) at the beginning of each new text. Flourished initials with alternately red and blue grounds at major textual divisions flourished in the other colour.
Incipits and explicits in red. Paraph marks in red or blue.
Maniculae throughout, but particularly ff. 1r-4r.

note.p: Interlinear and marginal annotations in dark ink throughout. Marginal annotations in faint red-brown crayon throughout.
In the margin of f. 34v, written in a tiny script, 'xma pecia debet incipi hac in linea'.

origin.origPlace: Probably copied in France, perhaps in Paris.
origin.p: Date of production suggested based on palaeographical features. Pam Robinson draws attention to a note on f. 34v which refers to pecia production: 'xma pecia debet incipi hac in linea’, and points out that the pecia system appears not to have been adopted in England.

provenance.p: Thomson notes in his Catalogue entry for the volume that a strip of parchment has been removed from the lower portion of f. 44, and speculates that the removed strip may once have contained information about a former owner.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 3 - Medical recipe collections (Thomson Part II)

msItem.title: Flores antidotarii (Extracts from the Antidotarium)
msItem.incipit: 45r Dyamargariton . pliris . zinziber . conditum
msItem.explicit: 47r Et est generale quod quidquid conpecit opilationi renum et uesice conpetit retentioni menstruorum
msItem.note: This text also appears in Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS Lat. 16193 , ff. 113r-116r.

msItem.title: Glosule antidotarii (Short gloss on the Antidotarium)
msItem.incipit: 47r Secundum quod uult auicenna practica diuiditur
msItem.explicit: 74v in membris pectoralibus inuiscati
msItem.note: There is a faded note in ink in a medieval hand following the explicit: correcte a somerset.

msItem.title: Notes on remedies
msItem.incipit: 74v Notandum quod petrosilium ruta liquiricia decocta in uino et gargarizata
msItem.explicit: 74v scias reperat uires in corpore debilium

msItem.title: Medical uses of roses
msItem.incipit: 74v Rosa frigida in primo gradu et sicca in secundo
msItem.explicit: 74v in aqua cocte
msItem.note: Written in the inner, outer, and lower margins in an anglicana hand.

msItem.title: De conferentibus et nocentibus
msItem.author: ?Arnaldus, de Villanova, d. 1311 (attrib.)
msItem.rubric: 75r Incipit liber de conferentibus et nocentibus
msItem.incipit: 75r Conferunt cerebro fetida ut in graui oppillatione cerebri
msItem.explicit: 78v omne nimis uentosum
msItem.finalRubric: 78v Explicit liber de nocentibus et conferentibus

supportDesc.condition: Folios 45-50 have sustained damage and are all missing irregular diagonal portions of their leaves extending from the middle of their head edges to the middle of their fore edges; some text has been lost due to this damage. Minor staining and rubbing on most leaves in this Part, some text partly illegible.

p.seg: Folios 45r-46v are ruled in four-column format, frame and lines for the capitula to the main text. Ruled in leadpoint, 45 lines to the column, written below top line.
Folios 47r-74v are ruled in two-column format, frame and lines. Ruled in leadpoint 40-45 lines to the column, written below top line.
Folios 75r-78v are ruled in three-column format, frame and lines. Ruled in leadpoint 40-45 lines to the column, written below top line.

handNote.p: The main text in this Part is written in the Gothic Rotunda form of northern European textualis.
There are marginal annotations in this Part in at least two Anglicana hands of the 15th century.

decoNote.p: Larger pen-flourished initials in red and blue at the opening of each text in this Part, e.g., f. 47r. Smaller pen-flourished initials in red and blue at the opening of major sections of each text in this Part.
Rubricated (red only) section heaings. Red frame outlines around section headings in brown ink in the margins.
Paraph marks in red and blue.

origin.origDate: Probably last quarter of the 13th century or the first quarter of the 14th century.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 4 - Isagoge of Iohannitus, Aphorisms of Hippocrates, Prognostics of Hippocrates, Tegni of Galen (Thomson Part III)

msItem.title: Isagoge ad Artem paruam Galeni (tr. Constantinus Africanus) [Latin]
msItem.author: Johannitius (b. 809, d. 873)
msItem.incipit: 79r Medicina diuiditur in duas partes
msItem.explicit: 94r boni maliue discretione

msItem.title: Verse on hours and humours
msItem.incipit: 80v A nona noctis donec sit tertia lucis
msItem.explicit: 80v Posthaec phlegma venit donec sit nona quietis
msItem.note: Also in Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek Codex Latinus Monacensis 13066, f. 82r.

msItem.title: Note on medical degrees
msItem.incipit: 81r Primus dicatur in quo sensus dominator
msItem.explicit: 81r Destractos sensus nescit precedere quartus

msItem.title: Aphorismata (Aphorisms) (tr. Constantinus Africanus) [Latin]
msItem.author: Hippocrates
msItem.incipit: 95r Uita breuis ars uero longa
msItem.explicit: 111v ut deglutire non possit mortale

msItem.title: Medical note
msItem.incipit: 112r Sanguinis incensi colere medicina peruste
msItem.explicit: 112r Archice paralis uomitus tremor atque diapnes

msItem.title: Prognostica (Prognostics) (tr. Constantinus Africanus or Gerard of Cremona) [Latin]
msItem.author: Hippocrates
msItem.incipit: 113r Omnis qui de medicine artis studio seu gloriam seu delectabilem amicorum copiam consequi desiderat
msItem.explicit: 120v exposite sunt ordine preceptorum
msItem.note: Pam Robinson has noted that an annotation in the lower margin of f. 115v, 'contra H de Burgo', probably refers to Prior Henry of Lanercost who died in 1315.

msItem.title: Medical verse
msItem.incipit: 120v Cum transiret Caesar per viam vidit monumentum ubi Ypocrates erat positus
msItem.explicit: 121v si super ceruicem uel umbilicum

msItem.title: Tegni (Latin)
msItem.author: Galen
msItem.incipit: 122r Tres sunt omnes doctrine
msItem.explicit: 155v in digestione egra nec digestionem nota

collation.p:
In Part 4, each of the main texts was copied on a physically distinct booklet or group of booklets, as follows: ff. 79-94 (Quires 10-11), 95-112 (Quires 12-13), 113-121 (Quire 14) and 122-155 (Quires 15-17). The text on Quires 15-17 ends imperfectly, indicating the loss of one or more quires after Quire 17.
Quire 1012 (ff. 79-90)
Quire 114 (ff. 91-94)
Quire 1212 (ff. 95-106)
Quire 136 (ff. 107-112)
Quire 1412-3 (ff. 113-121: 10th, 11th and 12th leaves missing)
Quire 1512-2 (ff. 122-131: 1st and 2nd leaves cancelled)
Quire 1614 (ff. 132-145)
Quire 1710 (ff. 146-155)

signatures.p: Medieval quire signature 'IIus' (secundus - the 2nd) in the lower margin of f. 94v, which is the last verso of Quire 11, the second quire in this Part of the manuscript.

supportDesc.condition: Minor stains and tears on several leaves in this Part.

p.seg: Single-column format, no ruling media visible except for ff. 75r-94r where faint ruling in leadpoint is occasionally visible. Typically 22 lines to the page, written below top line, frequent interlinear annotations and annotations in the generous marginal space.

handNote.p: The main text in this Part is written in the gothic rotunda form of northern European textualis.
The annotations in this Part are written in a very small libraria form of northern European textualis by at least two scribes.
Ownership inscription added to f. 115v in a northern textualis of 14th century appearance.

decoNote.p: Puzzle initial in red and blue with pen-flourishing at the opening of each text in this Part, e.g., f. 79r.
Plain red and blue initials at minor divisions of the text in this Part.
Rubricated headings (red only) at minor divisions of the texts in this Part.
Paraph marks in red and blue throughout this Part.

origin.origPlace: Written in England, perhaps in Lanercost Priory in Cumbria.
origin.p: Date and place of production based on palaeographical features. A Lanercost origin for this Part is plausible based onreferences to the community of Lanercost within the volume, although as the Lanercost references in this Part are later than the main copying stints, the Lanercost references may have been added at Lanercost later after Part 4 was copied elsewhere.

provenance.p:
Ownership inscription in the lower margin of f. 79r: Liber Sancte Marie magdalene de Lanrecost
Si quis inde eum asportauerit anathema sit.
(Book of Saint Mary Magdalene of Lanrecost
If anyone carries it away from there let him be anathema). The inscription refers to Lanercost PrioryLanercost Priory (Gilsland, England) in Cumbria, England. Another note on f. 115v, 'contra H de Burgo', probably refers to Prior Henry of Lanercost who died in 1315. See Pam Robinson's introduction to this record for further information.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 5 - Hippocrates, Philaretus, medical recipes and guidelines for bloodletting (Thomson Part IV)

msItem.title: Prognostica (Prognostics) (tr. Constantinus Africanus or Gerard of Cremona) [Latin]
msItem.author: Hippocrates
msItem.incipit: 156r Omnis qui artis medicine studio seu gloriam
msItem.explicit: 160r sunt exposite ordine preceptorum
msItem.note: Additional texts added to a blank space on f. 157r (see below); the 'main text' of the Prognostica continues correctly on f. 157v.

msItem.title: Note on inauspicious days for bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 157r Beda dicit de ultima die luna decembris
msItem.explicit: 157r nuncquam febricitabit . et est

msItem.title: Liber pulsuum (On Pulses) [Latin]
msItem.author: Philaretus
msItem.incipit: 160r Intencionem habemus in presenti
msItem.explicit: 161v et hoc nobis sufficiant ad presencia

supportDesc.condition: The leaves in this Part are affected by minor staining and rubbing. Large hole in f. 158 is the result of the parchment preparation process rather than later damage as text on the leaf conforms to the shape of the hole.

p.seg: Ruled in single-column format, frame and lines. Ruled faintly in leadpoint, 46 lines to the page, written below top line. Substantial marginal annotations in the generous margins around the main text.

handNote.p: Written in the gothic rotunda form of northern European textualis.

handDesc.handNote: Marginal annotations in several anglicana hands contemporary with the main text.

decoNote.p: Plain initials in red at the major and minor divisions of the text in this Part. Some minor initials in dark ink and touched with red.
Paraph marks in red in this Part.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 6 - Iohannitus and Hippocrates (Thomson Part V)

msItem.title: Isagoge ad Artem paruam Galeni (tr. Constantinus Africanus) [Latin]
msItem.author: Johannitius
msItem.incipit: 162r Medicina diuiditur in duas partes
msItem.explicit: 168v Membrum uel os egreditur a propria inunctura

msItem.title: Aphorismata (Aphorisms) (tr. Constantinus Africanus) [Latin]
msItem.author: Hippocrates
msItem.incipit: 169r et inanicio si quidem qualem oportet fieri fiat et confert et bene ferunt
msItem.explicit: 169v non in multitudinem considerari sed quomodo

supportDesc.condition: Leaves are lightly stained and have irregular edges. Some text lost to rubbing.

p.seg: Ruled in single-column format in hardpoint (some crayon ruling on f. 198). Ruling is not totally regular, typically 25-27 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The main text in this part is written in an informal northern textualis.
The marginal annotations and interlinear glosses in this part are written by at least two scribes both writing the English form of cursive script known as Anglicana.

decoNote.p: Outline illustration of a physician holding a (?urine) flask on f. 167r.

Flourished initial in red with "puzzle" construction and black acanthus-flourishing on f. 162r. Minor flourished initials in red or black in the "arabesque" style at the openings of some minor sections of the texts.
Plain initials in red or black at the openings of some minor sections of the texts.
Rubricated headings (red only) throughout this Part of the manuscript.

origin.origDate: Late 12th century or first half of the 13th century.
origin.origPlace: England, perhaps at Lanercost Priory in Cumbria.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 7 - Medical recipes, thunder prognostic, charms (Thomson Part VI)

msItem.author: Hermes Trismegistus (attrib.)
msItem.title: Thunder prognostic
msItem.incipit: 171r In quocunque signo tonitrum siue in die
msItem.explicit: 171r mutationes quam maxime consideruntur
msItem.note: Also in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Canon Misc. 517, f. 20r.

p.secFol: 171r In quocunque signo tonitrum siue in die

collation.p:
A bifolium with two inserted singletons after the first leaf.
Quire 202+1+1 (ff. 170-173; bifolium with two inserted singletons after the first leaf)

supportDesc.condition: The leaves in this part are irregular: folios 171 and 172 are ~40 mm shorter than the majority of the leaves in the volume; f. 172 has a tear in the upper inner corner that occured after the text was written.

p.seg: All of the leaves in this Part differ in their layout. Folios 171-173 are particularly informal in their layout.

handNote.p: The main text on f. 170r is written in gothic rotunda.

handDesc.handNote: Annotations on f. 170r by at least two scribes writing Anglicana hands. Text on ff. 171-173 also by scribes writing Anglicana hands.

decoNote.p: Plain initials in dark ink touched with red on f. 170r.
Paraph marks in red on f. 170r.

origin.origDate: Second half of the 13th century or the first half of the 14th century.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 8 - Ricardus Anglicus (Thomson Part VI continued)

msItem.title: Compendium de re medica (Compilation On Medical Matters)
msItem.author: Ricardus Anglicus
msItem.incipit: 174r Cum nostra compilatio ex prolixitate pauperibus uideatur honerosa
msItem.explicit: 174v et in arthritico de melancholia fit cura paralysis mortificacionis
msItem.note: This text also appears in London, British Library, Sloane MS 351, ff. 95r-156v .

supportDesc.condition: Leaf is rubbed and stained in several places and some of the text is now illegible.

p.seg: Ruled in hardpoint and very faint crayon, in two-column format. Typically 49 lines to the column, written above top line.

handNote.p: Written in an extremely small textualis libraria.

decoNote.p: Plain initials in red at the minor divisions of the text.

origin.origDate: Last quarter of the 12th century or the first quarter of the 13th century.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 9 - Medical definitions and a diagram (Thomson Part VI continued)

msItem.title: Definitiones physico-medicae
msItem.incipit: 175r Theorica est scientia cognoscendi sanitatis egritudinis et neutralitatis
msItem.explicit: 175r impedimentum fit illius operacionis quam perfatia a virtute . cuius inuani est ab ii humor

supportDesc.condition: The leaf is rubbed and stained and some text on f. 175r is difficult to read.

p.seg: Text is written in a single unruled column roughly half the width of the page. 35 lines of text.

handNote.p: At least three scribes writing various 14th century English cursive scripts.

decoNote.p: Unfinished circular diagram in dark ink on f. 175v.

binding.p: Rust stains on f. 175 (but not on ff. 176-178) suggest that before joining the rest of the material in Peterhouse MS 247, this leaf was a pastedown or an endleaf in a volume with a binding fitted with metal fastenings.

origin.p: Date of production assigned based on identification of persons named on the leaf. Place of possible production (and certain later ownership) based on identification of persons named on the leaf.

provenance.p: An inscription on f. 175r indicates that the leaf was part of a volume owned by Lanercost Priory in Cumbria, England, by 1354 at the latest: Liber ffratris Nicholai de Morland ex dono Willelmi de Langedale cuius usum proprium idem Nicholaus concessit cessit Domino Iohanni de Buchaster (The book of Nicholas of Morland from the gift of William of Langdale, the use of which the same Nicholas had granted to master John of Bewcastle). The inscription names three men (Nicholas of Morland and John of Bewcastle who were granted the use of a book by William de Langdale), and of the three, only John of Bewcastle can be supplied with further biographic information as he was Prior of Lanercost (1338-1354). As Pam Robinson points out, Bewcastle, Morland and Langdale are all Cumbrian place names and so the three men mentioned in the inscription are probably all linked by geographic ties as well as social and religious connections.

change.persName: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries
